conclusion: Analyze how shadows A, B, C, and D change when the light source moves to the back right.
The image shows a table with colored blocks (yellow, purple, brown, blue) and two fabric-like objects (red and multicolored).
Blocks are labeled A (yellow), B (purple), C (brown), D (blue) in the second image.
Assume blocks A, B, C, and D are elevated above the table surface, casting shadows labeled A, B, C, and D.
Assume initial light source position is front left above the objects.
With light source to the front left, shadows are cast to the back right of each object.
Blocks are clustered in the center of the table: A and B on the left, C and D on the right.
Initial shadow positions: A and B's shadows are slightly more to the left, C and D's shadows more to the right.
Initial shadow size: Shadows are elongated due to the angle of the light.
Light source moves to the back right, positioned above the objects.
With light source in the back right, shadows shift to the front left of each object.
New shadow positions: A, B, C, and D's shadows are now to the front left of their respective objects.
Shadows maintain the same relative arrangement as the objects.
New shadow size: Shadows remain elongated but now in the front-left direction.
Assume height of objects and light source angle remain constant.
Shadows' sizes remain similar in area to their initial sizes.
Summarize: Shadows shift from back right to front left, maintaining relative positions and similar sizes.
Final answer: Shadows A, B, C, and D move to the front left, maintaining relative positions and similar sizes.
